Name: Going Home: A Novel (The Survivalist Series)

ReviewList.Text: Ever wonder what would happen if it all came apart?  This author does an excellent job of telling a story of what could happen during a life changing event where the world as you know it no longer exists.  I've read many books throughout the years and have to say this is defintiely one of the best in this genre.  We as a modern society have insurance on practically everything...car, life, home, etc.  What insurance do we have on our family and the ability to keep them safe in a world gone mad?  How would you make it back to your loved ones if the grid went down and you found out your car and cell phone were affected by a catastrophic event?  Do you have the means in your vehicle to travel 50 miles or so on foot?  In the middle of a Southern drought or Northern frigid winter?  Do you have a plan in place for your wife and children to survive a prolonged event without assistance during your absence?  If you think you can count on "Big Brother" to be there when you need him the most, look what happened during recent hurricane events.  This story is definitely an eye opener and highly recommended.  Once you start you won't want to put it down.

Have been captivated by this book since its conception on a forum. The author is vivid in detail and immerses you in the day to day struggle of Morgan on his journey home. I have read about every doomsday novel / short story out there and this one is story I will read over and over. Great Job A.American!

I purchased this novel after reading Alas Babylon and One Second After.  Although the story line is similar the book falls way short.  The author writes in the style of a middle schooler with short choppy sentences.  His use of abbreviations without explanation is puzzling.  The premise that he is carrying a backpack in his car with rations, guns, ammo, night vision goggles is to far fetch.

This story will draw you in and keep your attention from beginning to end.  It is a real eye opener for those who haven't thought of our world without the electrical grid and the modern appliances we all depend on daily. I have read other similar stories, this one is my favorite. I can't wait for AA's next installment in this series.

This book... Where to start. Obnoxious, unnecessary, and incessant detailing was put into describing EVERYTHING in this book. He could have said things like ;"The man pulled his knife"...  but instead he said things like; "The man pulled his Buck Model 110, The world's #1-selling hunting knife in its original lock-back design. 4" stainless-steel clip blade. Brass bolsters and liners. 4 7/8" closed length. Black leather flapped sheath. USA." It was so annoying that I would skip paragraphs at a time because they were all redundant descriptions. Another thing that made me hate this book is that the main character was completely unrealistic and predictable. He could literally do no wrong, plus he had the PERFECT thing in his backpack for litterally every situation. Had the gravity on earth failed, I'm positive he would have had a Nasa Moon Suit in his 'Maxpedition Devildog'. This author needs to read a few good books and take a lesson.

This is a riveting story from start to finish. It is well written, and has an addicting way of drawing you into the characters and the story. Be warned, once you start, you will not be able to put this down until the end, and it will leave you wanting more. Luckily Book II is just around the corner..

This is my first review for a book. I felt I needed to write a few words because this book left me wanting.  When you take the leap in your mind that somehow there are everyday people out there that go around with a survival pack in their cars, fitted with NVGs, MREs gun, etc then the story is decent for a while.  Only to (spoiler alert) to have to take another leap that this fellow finds the "perfect" prepper in his travels who fixes a big hole in his head.  Anyway lets just say in the end I got the feeling that I wasted a lot of time for nothing.  Its setup for a follow up book but if one comes I am not buying.

If you enjoy a story that draws you in, then this is the book for you....but be warned once you pick it up you won't want to put it down. I have been following this writer while he was writing and it is the best book, best written, great storyline of any book I have read and is for any and everyone!  This is the first of hopefully many, he is writing the second one now. I would love to see this as a TV series or movie - little or big screen.
Before you start this book, you will need to study the glossary. I wish the author would have just written out what he was trying to say.  Editing in this book is AWFUL.

Bought this book because of the high reviews. Wow, what a mistake. There is no character development. Detail??not on the characters, the sourroundings or anything deserving imagery. What i did get was detail on his pack and it's contents and how the items were used. I also got a run down of every meal and his lodging setups. I didn't know that the main characters clothes were in earth tones until the last part of the book. Hair color? Eye color? Height? Weight? Not a clue. I learned that he lost weight from his trek in the final chapters but not how much and I definitely didn't have a starting weight to gauge the change and truly feel his struggle. I felt disconnected from the story and truly didn't care if the main character and his compadres lived or died. I actually got bored reading it and had to push through to finish it. Save your time and money.

Seriously guys-we're all Americans, even the ones you call "sheeple," even the ones you say got free phones from Obama and are dependent on welfare. There is no government conspiracy, no EMP bombs. Just Americans doing the best they can with what they have.

I just got this book in hardback and liked it so much I am going for the Kindle edition as well. If you want a picture of what might be the very real future read this. An EMP would devastate this nation and being even 100 miles away from home would be a major danger to your survival. Always try to be prepared because even a small problem could become major if you are stuck without what you need.

One of the very best books of the genre, and even if you aren't into this particular genre of post-shit-hit-the-fan type novels, this is an excellent adventure read.  I first came across this story online and it was painful to wait for the next chapter to be posted.  This story will hook you quick.  I am getting another copy for my Kindle.  Buy it -- you won't be disappointed.
Pretty bad, it's like reading a giant advertisement for all the gear he uses, Ridiculous,

So much better then patriots.  All about the will to fight and to live.  Not a "how to" book, not a bunch of over explained crap, just a good story and a good amount of action.  The main character Morgan seams realistic, the story flows well, and you can't help but cheer him home

I'm about 3/4 of the way through the book and I'm giving up.  I've had all I can take of the weightless, infinite capacity backpack the main character carries.  If a real person could actually carry all the stuff the main character humps over several hundred miles, no one would need a bug out location!  The main character carries a backpack and a variety of other bags with every gadget & good idea known to prepperdom.  No backpack made could carry all the crap this guy has and, if it could, a real person couldn't get it off the ground, much less hump it a couple hundred miles through swamps and forest.  **SPOILER ALERT** The pruning shears are the last straw!  I'm now searching for entertainment elsewhere.

Great book from beginning to the end.  My only problem with the book was the total lack of editing.  Typos, grammar, sentence structure were distracting.  In spite of that, it's still one of the best books I've read in a long time.  From some of the other reviews I've read, it appears there will be another book that will continue Morgan's story. I'm looking forward to its release.

This book was in serious need of an editor . Filled with grammatical and spelling errors .  Also , if you are opposed to profanity , this book is not for you . Overall , it was a good storyline and could have been so much better with a few changes.

WOW!  A. American weaves an incredible, believable, down to earth tale.  This could happen to Mr. Average given the right circumstances!  Prepare to be up late reading!  One of the best of this genre I have happened upon!  A must read!  Congratulations on your first novel.  Looking forward to the next!

I have followed A. American for awhile now. He has a way of producing characters the bring them to life like all the great authors do. I will warn you that once you start reading you will not be able to stop. It has been a long wait, but worth it. This is a must buy.

I was able to read the on going work on a forum and the second book (in progress) is just as good.  I've read the others...Patriot, etc. and I clearly rate this head and shoulders above the rest of them.  You won't be able to put it down.
This book is a great reality check. What would you do? Makes you think. This book is a great read with some deep issues and humor included. Highly recommended

The author did a great job on character development and the story moved right along.  I also enjoyed the limited number of main characters because some stories end up with too many characters to follow.  Being a retired Marine I was able to connect with Sarge and his Army crew and enjoyed their portion of the story.  Reading some other review comments, they said the military jargon and the way they acted doesn't happen in the real world, but it actually does.  Former military personnel always bring their miltary service into their civilian life, which help the book with humor and some pretty great gun battles.  Morgan is a likeable guy, who basically prepared for everything and I think part of the story was to sell all the survivalist gear he described in detail throughout the book.  Again, excellent job on the story and I enjoyed the four part cliff hangers for the next book.  I am looking forward to book 2.
The Author writes in 3rd person and says verybodys names repeatidly to the point of exhaustion,The story line isnt bad just needs Edited.
So many misspelled words and grammatical errors I had to put it down. Couldn't finish it. Badly in need of an editor and spell check.
Great plot, but poorly written. Hard to read - the writing style was rudimentary and sentence structure at times awkward.

This is the first book from the kindle market place that I did not finish (only read 6%). My main issues with this one had to do with poor writing and unnecessary detail when it comes to describing mundane details. The author particularly focusses on the main character's equipment going down to give specific nomenclature, model number, and other unimportant details of gear that would have been better served in a list of materials to be included in a bug out bag. The actions of the characters did not seem believable, and did not fit with how they were presented. I will attempt to give this book another chance at a later point.

This book, and the "Deep Winter" series, is what got me to actually start the proverbial "Saving for a Rainy Day".  Truly an enjoyable read...though not for the faint of heart and sensibilities.  If you're easily offended, go buy a Sesame Street book.  If you enjoy what could become a real life adventure, with all of true-to-life grit thrown in, then GET THIS BOOK!  Not only is the book entertaining, but it's informative and instructional at the same time, without you even realizing that you are gaining the skill and mindset to overcome just about any serious event/natural disaster that may come your way.  I've not only bought the Kindle version, but I've also ordered the Hardcover so that IF things go awry, I'll have a physical "how-to" manual.

This is one of the best books I have read in along time and I beg for a sequel from this author.  I am a marine combat vet. Vietnam and this writer sees the true writing on the wall.  It is a adventure in depth , length and brilliance.  Please continue on with the story and your insight.  I HATE to see what is in our future.  I shall see you in the foxhole,  l am afraid, as our country caves in to socialism.  Best to you.  A. American.  What a fitting handle.  THERE ARE A FEW OF US LEFT.  USMC

I enjoyed this book and would buy the next.  Yes there are some editing errors but over all it did what a good book should.  Kept my attention and made me think what I would do in the situation.  Some good subtle prepping tips are written in as well.  Being military I can relate to a lot of things I read about.  Some I agree with and the others I can let go and not be that critical in the name of entertainment.  It's not easy to be a good writer and having tried a few times I know this the hard way.  I think any prepper will get a kick out of this book.  Nice twist on starting the character out on the road when the SHTF.  Much better than keeping him home when it all starts.  That's been played out by other authors.  Good luck on the next book and or books... Hint hint.... Lol.

A bit simplistic in places and too many technical terms and initials.  I read the Kimble version and it wasn't until the end of the book in the annexure that I found what all the initials etc meant.  Not a bad yarn but the whole survivialist thing is rather a strange concept for an Aussie to grasp.

I purchased this book after reading the high four-star rated reviews and quickly came to regret my decision.  This book is the most poorly written piece of fiction I've attempted to read in a long time.  I had to reread many sentences just to try to get the flow of what was happening; the verb tense kept switching back and forth from present to past--even in the same sentence!  The book is about an egotistical, sadistic, foul-mouthed prepper with no respect for others.  God help us if there are more preppers out there like this one.  He claims not to have the inventory of Walmart, but then spends pages describing all the latest prepper gadgets outside of an average person's ability to buy.  I had to apologize to God for purchasing this one and ask Amazon for my money back.  Please save yourself the headache of purchasing this book.

I couldn't put this one down! The story, characters, and style were vivid and real, even the hard choices being made and there personal impacts to the characters. Even if you are not a fan of the genre, this is one of the best put there to get your feet wet. All of the info without feeling like you are reading a how-to manual. It made me think about "what if" and also "could I do that?" throughout. I hope I never need to match this stories journey, but thanks to this book, find myself searching out more ways to be ready for whatever life throws our way.

The majority of People living in America think that their government will always be there to protect them. They have never stopped to think about how they would survive if a breakdown of civilization occurred. The people who have prepared for themselves and their families will survive while the rest will quickly perish. This gifted writer has possibly provided us with a very prophetic vision of the future.

If you believe 1) the conspiracy theory nuts, 2) an overweight, middle aged man can carry a 60 pound pack for hundreds of miles, 3) all the "bad guys" are incompetent idiots, 4) the good guys ALWAYS have the best luck in violent confrontations, and 5) care about the brand name of every item in the 60 pound pack or any other weapon or item the characters come across, you may be able to finish this book.  But if you are not crazy enough to believe that crap, you will find the book to be CRAP.

Didn't want to stop reading. Geat characters, too real scenarios and i hope this eally never happens. However, if you read this and it doesn't motivate you to prepare then you deserve what you get. Great book!
It has been years since I have made the time to actually sit down and read a book. I was immediately drawn in and found myself craving the next fix!

When I first looked at the reviews for this book, I though,Wow, this guy got 40 or more of his friends to give him five starts. I have not come across another book with that many reviews with all five stars and nothing else. But after reading it I have to totally agree that this is one of the best SHTF books I have read. The story is of a man on a sales trip caught away from home when a EMP/CME type event happens taking down the entire grid. He luckily has his emergency bag in his car and starts the long walk back home. Along the way he meets up with others and is soon involved in a struggle against a rogue government trying to take advantage of the situation. The book is very well written, even the dialogue between characters is believable. The only disappointment I have is that I noticed the book just came out so I'll have to wait that much longer for the second part.
A Americans writing style is very unique .He draws you in and you cant let go. Be prepared for some very late night reading.
This is a great book, with a very gripping story. If you are a fan of PAW fiction this book is for you.
This one is the absolute winner of the PAW novels. Be fore warned, once you start you can not stop.

Loved, Loved, Loved this first book. The next two books were great to read as well but didn't impact me as much as this first one. Going Home provides much more instruction, somewhat similar to "Patriots" by James Wesley Rawles. I've purchased several items based on what I read in this first book. However, once the character is home it's more about the social interaction than gear or supplies. The character development in all the books is fantastic and when it finally wraps up, you'll miss them all and wish there was more.

This is one of those rare books that you not only find hard to put down but you learn a lot from as well.  I know books have to end somewhere, but I hoped this one never would.  The story line is extremely plausible, in fact likely in my personal opinion.  If you want to prep and "get your head right" for the occasion, read this one.  This is a story that can support several or many more books.  Author's choice, I guess.  Go for it, A!

I really enjoyed the concept and the action/adventure.My only problem with the book was the lack of character background and development of the main character.You have his name,family and where he is from, and you get little hints that maybe he served in the Marines by his use of certain terminology.I am looking forward to future books by this author, but maybe more background info on your main character!

This book has had me on the edge of my seat, and made me love reading again. I stopped reading books years ago, but had the pleasure of reading this one as it was being written. This is a frightening reality of what could and just might happen in the world we live in today. It'll make you think twice about preparing for the worst! A true wake up call to those who think the government will always provide and protect them. NOT!

I would give an A- for storyline and plot, and a D for writing quality and editing.  I was stressed by the constant "salty" language of the characters, and felt that the author used unnecessary swearing to add emphasis and reality and to prop up poor writing.  I bought the series before I read the first book and am now sorry.
I was originally skeptical about the quality when I first purchased it.  Once I got into it, I could not put it down. I immediately bought the sequel and it is just as good.
I am afraid this could be so close to the truth to human behavior. I will be reading the series.

I liked the story line, but it wasn't the closeness to the charectors as in other books. In other words we didnt feel close to the charectors.  But over all a good read. Will buy the next I  the series of books.

A smooth clearly written story. One book takes up where the other leaves. A lot of "gun talk". (Types of guns) which I didn't know much about. It was till a great read. No romance, so, if you want that included, you need to skip this.. Fighting, gangs, war, zombies.
Good book.  A little on the unbelievable side, but still useful and thought-provoking.  Worth the price, and I look forward to the next one.

I give it four out of five stars for the unique story line and the characters that most can can relate to. At the start I was looking for a little more scene description but as the story progressed I got caught up in the survival  mode the main character was in and the thought this could easily happen in America. The crude language  throughout was disappointing  and would keep me from recommending it to kids to read.  This would make great movie!
Its a good story, that has been written multiple times here lately.  Good enough I will get book 2.  Not as good as lights out, or one second after but was descent.  Like the getting home story line

This story is great and truly sucks you into the main characters thoughts.  I liked it mostly because I travel for work and always what would I do if something happened while I was away from my home.  This book is definitely not a gear guide, but truly an exciting story about a journey home.  I went out and read the next two books immediately.

For someone who travels a lot like I do, the premise of the book is good to stir thought and some of the scenarios are good to make one think of what should be in their survival bag.  The profanity is just excessive.  I've served in the Navy, and I work in automotive repair, so it is not that my ears are too sensitive, but just because I have to listen to it at work doesn't mean I want to read it at home.  By choosing to write the book the way the author did, he lost a segment of his audience because I won't refer this to my church friends, my adult children, etc.  My family can read The Patriot and get the same information (although with The Patriot the reader can tell they are being taught, not just entertained).

I enjoyed reading this book although the first 25 pages I said, "You gotta be kidding me!" about 100 times.  If you can get through listing the name brand of every single item in the man's pack, then you might just enjoy it.  I've lived in this area of Florida for a long time and I don't believe I've EVER heard a hillbilly redneck like the ones in the book. I know there's a difference in Country Boy and Redneck, but even the rednecks have evolved a little over the years...I think...maybe I just never see them??? You'll shake your head at how ANYBODY would carry so much stuff in his car... even a serious Prepper. I have to agree with the soldiers who wrote a review and all their comments. Everything they said, I thought or said out loud. But I still enjoyed reading it.  Maybe I got interested because the characters were right in my home town....
Liked it so much I ordered the sequel.  It's a little more real than other end of the world books like it.

I will start out saying that the story is really good. Unfortunately the writing could really be improved. The author seems caught up in using the terms that preppers use. But I get the idea. It seems that he is trying to teach how to get prepared and the thimgs that could be needed. It does teach these things, but would probably do well to have someone do some editing.  But if you can over look these things, the story is worth reading.
The book is an easy read. I just shook my head at all the equipment he had with him. I don't think so. That was a little over the top. Not as well written as I would have liked. Good base story.

I enjoyed the book & it certainly gave you something to think about & what is needed to be prepared in case of an emergency but the book got a little slow at times especially the long descriptions, it really shouldn't take a whole paragraph to describe putting up a clothes line. But with that said it was a good book & I would recommend it for both a good read as well to learn what is needed for emergency preparedness.
A reality check on the current mindset of a large portion of the American population unfortunately. Hope there is a sequel. A thoroughly enjoyable read.

I really enjoyed the story. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is the editing. The author goes through a couple where he changes tenses, etc and it is a little distracting. It wouldn't be such a problem if the story wasn't so good. I highly recommend the book.

While overall I liked this book, it seemed to me that it went from being realistic -- what was encountered on the road -- to a bit over the top with the reason WHY all of the conspiracy was taking place. I do not know if the author really believes that his reasoning is realistic, but it did not make any sense to me, and thus the 4 stars rather than 5. Another problem with the book is that at times the dialog was over the top. Would I recommend this book to those who like post-apocalyptic novels? I would. I also wished that we had gotten a bit more information as to what the thumb drive contained...
Loved the characters, you felt like you knew them and what their next move would be..hope that there is a sequel that picks up where this one stops.

The story and characters were good but there were just to many descriptions that went on and on. How many times do you have to read about how someone shaves or cooks? Would have been better to just get on with the story.
Very descriptive and accurate.  Like able characters and good action scenes.  9 more words required.  5 more words required. Required.
This book will make you think and be an entertaining read at the same time. Read it and improve your chances of getting home if an EMP hits!
A good story. The only thing that stretches credibility is the fact that the central character has everything in his backpack. How big is that thing?

The writing was a bit rough with simplistic action and plot twists. But the characters were compelling and likable. All in all it felt like a good first effort, as the novel got more sophisticated in its grammer and plot. I look forward to a follow up. I do enjoy the main characters and it has definitely set the table for more chapters.
Good plot, kept me going. Very irritating dialog slang kept the flow stilted. The author needs a worthy editor. Overall a good write for an amateur author
Good book.  I am enjoying the apocalypse genre these days and this one didn't dissapoint.  Good character development and story line.  Good set up for the next in the series.  I'll wait for it.

This book was not bad.  A few editing errors but overall well written.  The story was a bit stop n go with too much of an attempt at describing every little detail at times.  Not a bad read for the genre and worth the time overall.

A. American's novel Going Home is a breath of fresh air in a genre that is much too fond of zombies for my tastes. If you enjoy plot centered tales that focus on effective characterization to drive the story forward, you will love this novel. The author creates realistic characters that we easily relate to and empathize with. The events are well laid out and well paced so as to never allow the reader to get neither bored nor overwhelmed. Worth the price of admission.
Seemed a little like there were some product sponsors paying the author. Good fanatsy story though. Would read part two.
This book was okay and I enjoyed reading it. It wasn't the best book I've ever read but it was just fine for a short enjoyable read.

This is the fastest I've ever read any book. Great balance. Since I live in Florida I think that kept me interested all the more. I will say that at the end of the book I felt like I was being subjected to a sublimnal NRA fear tatic. That being said I will read the next book should it become a reality.

I enjoyed the book immensely.  The author is either very much into survival, or did a great deal of research.  I feel the author researched every aspect as there was nothing he introduced in his story that was not believable.  I was a bit disappointed in how abruptly the story came to an end, but it left me wanting to read more.  I am looking for the sequel now.  I would recommend this reading to anyone who wants to know what to look forward to in the event of any type of real catastrophic event.
Good scenario, fairly well written but lots of grammar and spelling errors.  Interesting enough that I will look for the next book!  Just hope the editor does a better job...
Although the editing wasn't great, parts of the story were frighteningly realistic about people handle a catastrophe, how ugly some can become, and how unprepared for any hardship most are.

This is one of the best post-apocalytic novels I've read...grabbed my interest and was very informative and the info is accurate. I read a lot of dystopian fiction and if it doesn't grab me quick I put it down and move on. I consider a book "good" if I can't stop thinking about it. I will buy other books by this author. Other books in this genre I recommend are "Earth Abides"  and "Dog Stars".
Great book I read a good chunk of it on SB. A couple of spelling errors but nothing too distracting from the book. Will be purchasing the next book in the series!

This book left me feeling like I needed a shower.  I found it callous and crass.  If you want to hear the "F" word every other sentence then perhaps it is for you.  As for me, I can't help but feel that if these are the kind of people that survive TEOTWAWKI then what is the point of even trying to survive it.  What a depressing book.

good details. lots of action. I dont read these types of books to analyze writing style or plot development. I consider them as a training manual for what has a very good chance of happening in this country. Cant wait to read the rest of this series. Took me three days to finish both books....can never get enough prepper fiction!

I am not a fan of novels written as thinly disguised political polemics, and that's what this is.  Rarely did anything happen that wasn't in some way related to his premise that most Americans are lazy welfare queens and that only gun-toting rugged individualists are worth anything.  In terms of literary quality, I had a difficult time believing this was not a self-published book.  There was very little action or suspense and when something did happen, I was rarely in doubt that the protagonists would be okay.  Very predictable stuff.  Normally, I rush to get sequels to post-apocalyptic novels even if they were mediocre because I can't get enough of the genre and I like to see how all the characters end up. In this case, however,  in the parlance of the book, ain't no way I'm gonna get part two.

The story was well thought out and the characters were believable, interesting and you want to find out more about their troubles.  As for the complaints about grammar and punctuation, give me a break.  They were not so gross or prevalent that they distracted from the story and not only should you  be aware this is an indie book, but the author in his preface tells you there may be issues.  Go with the flow and enjoy the story. Finally this is a survivalist story written from a survivalist point of view.  I am just surprised there are not more complaints referencing paranoia that our current president would do what he does in this story.  To me it is chilling that his actions are accepted as possible.

Really enjoyed this book, couldn't put it down. The author was well versed in the art of survival and I gathered quite a bit of information that I will utilize in the future. PLEASE tell me that there will be a followup to this book in the future! Well done!

Fast paced, poorly edited, sloppily written, characters and situations not believable (Barak O. nukes U.S. in order to "transform" it?!?) Too heavy on the paranoid goober gun nut politics. Did I say it`s fast paced? A. American, please buy a dictionary before you write the inevitable sequel.

good story.  lots of typos in the book.  the narrative is first person for the first half, then switches back and forth between fist and third.  strange choice.  overall, I laughed, I cried, and I learned something.  That's what I look for in a novel.

Okay, let me begin by saying this book is no literary masterpiece. Its a maybe 3 for this genre but I will up it to 4 for a couple reasons besides there is no 3.5 in Amazon's system. Many early poor reviews seem to be for a self-published version of this book that was a typo-grammar disaster. I read a 2013 revised version published (and edited) by Plume/Penguin. This is a prepper book about TEOTWAWKI. It's linked to a blog called angeryamerican.net. Like most prepper fiction, the plot is short on realism while the detailed descriptions of equipment are over the top. The reason for this is simple -- most prepper "novels" are infomercials for the prepper lifestyle and products. If you like prepper stuff, you tend to like the books. The worst part about this genre is that every protagonist seems super pleased that the end finally came and justified their decision to spend their children's college fund on the most expensive and redundant prepper gear/systems/plan imaginable. And because super-self-reliant people are ego-maniacs the protagonists are usually unpleasant (David Crawford has a decent prepper novel called Collision Course that deals with this obnoxious issue in an ironic way). They tend to look with utter disdain on anyone who wasn't as prepared as they were (John Wesley Rawles is the pioneer of these novels and his books are known for all these qualities). Morgan Carter is an above average character for this type. In fact, if you are willing to swallow some prepper Kool-Aid then you will better enjoy this infomercial. I did because I knew what I was getting into. I am a bit of an urban prepper and a veteran. Yes, the military stuff here is unrealistic and will bug veterans. No former First Sergeant will accept Sarge as a nickname. And the hero is carrying an RV on his back not a true bugout bag. No one in average physical shape will hump a 60 lbs. ruck over 200+ miles. And when you add up his gear (two of everything?!?!?), with water and MREs, you get closer to 100 lbs. But remember, its an infomercial. Morgans journey is a bit of a stretch. Cold water kills people in Florida winters (I was a winter Ranger at Eglin and wont forget that cold). So do head wounds with a 9 mm. Morgan survives both. The morality is a bit simplistic and the ending seems too good to be true. The surviving dystopian federal government isnt trying too hard with their martial law. But preppers need to believe their endgame scenario to justify the toys. They often mock the seriously religious in these books but prepper faith is almost a religion of its own. So BELIEVE, at least for this book, and enjoy yourself while taking notes for some cool toys. I like prepper toys myself -- especially guns. Recommended for preppers. And for non-preppers who want to read a better than average example from this genre.

Whoa, just going to azon to check the pubdate on this and wow, what a diverse reaction in the reviews!  It's got a strong 4 star rating with close to 800 reviews at this point in time so do I need to add another review, not really, but my impression anyway :-) This is a cross between post-apocalyptic and survivalist fiction.  The end of the world as we knew it as experienced by a few preparedness/survivalist/gung-ho/ex-military types and their families.  Nothing wrong with that!  Sounded interesting to me but a bit different from the usual dystopian post apocalypse novel being turned out today.  The scariness comes in knowing that these events and the way people in general react to them are realistic.  This could happen.  This is definitely aimed at men, whatever the opposite of chick lit is, that's what this is, barely a female present and testosterone oozing from the pages.  I haven't read anything like it since back in the day when I sampled a couple of Mack Bolan (The Executioner) books LOL  This read like an action movie for me; I could visualize it as it happened.  Lots of action and violence.  I mean the main guy kills three people before the book's barely started and they were "justifiable".  All the good guys kill bad guys all over the place and they are always "justifiable".  Really over the top, action hero movie violence.  If this was a serious book, these actions would be deplorable but set within this fictional world it was a lot of fun. I didn't like either of the young men who were trying to get back to their wives and kids but Sarge was a mean old coot with a heart in their somewhere and he's the only character I actually liked.  Anyway, this is one of those books, I'll say I loved, not for any literary merit but simply because it gave me an adrenaline rush and it was fun.  I have the second book on my Kindle and will be reading it soon.

Riveting story, and great writing!  AA spins a tale that will hold your attention and imagination like no other.  This disturbing and believable story will leave you wanting more! --- and there is more to come!

I've been a fan of these types of books for a long time.  This book is by far the best book on this subject that I've read.  I can only hope and pray that there will be a part two to this GREAT story.
This a great story! It will be impossible to set down until you finish! The characters are just normal everyday folks, who find themselves far from home when all he doubletoothpicks breaks loose!
Terrible.  This book was bad.  Don't waste your money.  And don't take the chance that your IQ might slip a few points from reading it.  This prepper fiction started out bad and is getting worse.
I thought the story and the storyline development was excellent. Easy to read and easy to imagine. The author is certainly subject intelligent and I am certainly looking forward to the next book.
I've read just about every PAW novel out there, This one hands down being the best.Be ready to be tired at work the next day because you absolutely will not be able to put the book down.
Excellent storyline, well thought out. Kept me engaged the entire book. I was sorry it ended! A few editing errors but nothing that would keep me from recommending this book.

Wow! How many words can describe such an awesome book! I was skeptical of this series of books simply because I'm a hardcore JWR fan, boy was i made a believer! I have always liked the "collapse/survival/doomsday" books and this one by far has got me hooked. From the beginning I was drawn in by the simple attitude of the main character and how he is an ordinary human that works for a living to feed his family vs the seemingly "million dollar a year salary" yahoos in all the other books I've read. Prior reviewers have complained about the use of profanity in this book, but I find it very suiting especially in the context it gets used. The author doesn't make the survivalists in this book seem like they've spent millions of dollars and half a century prepping for when the SHTF. As stated earlier, it's average joes that make this story happen and not lottery winning, wealthy oil tycoons hold up in a bunker. Sorry about going back to that point but that's where a lot of authors get it wrong, they act like it takes a lot of money to survive when mere common sense saves more lives than the golden child gadgets. Thank you for a great book!! I will be purchasing the rest soon!!!

I am a big fan of the survival/prepper genre, but I am sick of reading self-edited books that I purchased at full price, I'm talking basic typos. I've heard many of my peers say that books like these are a good way of introducing preparedness to friends, this is not the book I would use. Every problem seems to be fixed by an incredible turn of luck or  Morgan's endless bug-out-bag full of tricks. While the author displays some familiarity with small unit tactics and military gear I think your better bet is to read Rawles' "Patriots" while reviewing SH 21-76 (Ranger Handbook). Also, the protagonist uses Permithin (sp) treatment on his clothes and immediately puts them on, this is fine (at least from an emergency standpoint) but I think I have to warn everyone that these kits contain elements that are KNOWN to cause cancer, nasty ass cancer your friends will mock you for, so while treating one field uniform is fine, don't go dunking everything you own in this stuff.
It certainly has an attitude.  Not at all balanced.  I guess good hints on camping equipment/guns/etc. but the meanness was triumphant.

Great idea for a novel, poorly executed.  A regular guy gets stranded far from home and his journey to return to his family. Good character building with Morgan, Thad, and Jess.  So far so good.  Even good explainations of various equipment.  Now to the not so good.  The protagonist is not just a regular guy, but has been survival prepping for some time. He seems to be able to reach into his magic bag of tricks and is able to find anything he needs for just the right moment. He never really goes hungry or thirsty.  The 'bad guys' are cookie cutter one dimensional, very bad so it is no surprise they die often.  An EMP catastrophe is bad as is.  To add a government plot on top of that is just plain silly.  Then to add a resistance movement is more silliness.  This is the realm of the tin foil hat crowd.  Prior reviews were spot on for errors in spelling, punctuation, grammar and repeated sentences.  All of these detract from the story.  Good first attempt for the author.

Apparently the kindle version has been edited since the other reviewer posted, as I found very little to no errors with grammar and spelling.  I read a lot of this genre of books, and really enjoyed this one!  I had no trouble with the first person for the main character and 3rd person for the other characters, it made sense to me for it to be done that way.  While the author does go into some detail about actions the character are taking, I feel that level of detail adds to the color of the book, rather than being tedious.  It helps to keep the story flowing in the movie in my head as I read it.  I am looking forward to the next book, having read the preview.  There is a glossary in the back for the acronyms used in the book, anyone not familiar with prepping, or survival gear will not know what these mean.  While I read a lot of these books, I also did not know what some of them meant, so this is the only real flaw I can find in the tale.  Very enjoyable overall!

The prepping that was done by the hero was not realistic.  No one would have everything available that he had in case of an emergency while traveling.  A grill to cook on?  Really?  What was very realistic, is the effect that the lack of police had on some people.  As an eye witness to the 1992 LA riots that part of the book was excellent.  The need for violent action to protect one's self.  The hidden criminal behavior coming out and people taking charge in evil ways, I can see.  I could not conceive of a conspiracy to take our county down a year ago.  Now I can believe it happening a little everyday.  There is a lot to think about in this book.  One thing I had when I was on the road a lot was a long gun.  That would have made more sense than a grill.  Good book, too tied to the minutia of things kept to survive by name and company.  Almost sounded like an infomercial.  I hope there was no product placement in weriting the book.  .

My new favorite post apocalypse series!  With a good blend of action, plot development and practical prepping information “Going Home” is a fun read which draws you in and keeps you interested from start to finish.  Although it’s not, the writing made me thing of more of a journal being told (mostly) through the eyes of the main character Morgan.  It has a great bit of detail and takes you through his thought process making it easy to get engrossed in the story.  The characters are a bit static and the author’s ideology comes through loud and clear, but the story is just too good.  Also, I’d like to give a big thanks to the author for writing a series where the story continues from book to book but makes each one stand alone!  I am certainly going on to the next book but with this one being wrapped up so nicely I don’t feel as if I’m being made to read the next book to get the whole story!
Pretty good read. Well written, believable & realistic for a Survivalist story. I'll probably continue to read the series.

The story line is well put together and will keep you entertained. That being said this is one of the most unrealistic stories in this genre that I have come across. The main guy in the book is far more prepared than anybody would be traveling to and from work. It is pretty unrealistic what this guy has in his “GO” bag. Not saying it couldn’t happen, but unlikely. Course with most of these books the “GUY” gets home while killing every bad guy within minutes of a collapse without little remorse. This book is no different.  If you are a stickler for editing and/or spelling mistakes; then I would pass on this book. This is not normally a issue for me, but it was abundant in this book. This has to do more with the publisher than the author.  I know it sounds like I hated the book. Well I didn’t and would recommend it to someone that is a collector/reader of the genre…

The concept was something that really interested me.  How fast would society break down after a catastrophic event?  And where are the weak links?  What causes the most panic?  But from the get go this book was 70% howto manual with a lot of product advertising and recommendations for survivalist equipment.  Don't get me wrong I did do some online checking on some of the product listed in the book.  The other 30% of the book which was actually about the plot and character development was good and it grabbed my attention- only to be dashed against the jagged rocks of...."And so this is how you cook your MRE's with a heat pack."  This could go on for many pages, along with how to clean your knife and what to look for on the blade that indicates a cleaning is needed and so on and so on.  I doubt I will follow the series.

I've been reading a lot of the 'apocalyptic' style books lately, at first for fun but as I read more I started to realize that things like this, an EMP for example, are not so crazy.  I enjoyed the story line here but I also learned a lot from this novel.  I actually purchased a few items mentioned in this book to keep with me when I travel, just in case.  I often travel alone and always carry an emergency bag with me but this book enlightened me on a few things I was missing.  My husband is often gone for days at a time for work so I am alone most of the time, which is why I realized that I need to be self-sufficient if an emergency happens...Looking forward to the next book in the series.

This book has it all! At least everything I have thought about in a SHTF scenario. From using the bug out bag to dealing with nasty encounters along the way. I'm no literary genius, but some complained about punctuation and spelling. Sorry,I was too entrenched in the story to notice. The author wrote about everything dear to my heart, MRE's, M1 carbine, AK's, silver coin bartering, backwoods cigars, International Scout, and survival gear. Others complained about the details of the activities described, Once again I enjoyed it as he described exactly what was taking place and added to the insight on the use of his equipment. Of course I'm hooked and have ordered the rest of the series!

Like other reviews I'd start by saying it is a good story and worth the time if you appreciate post apocalyptic fiction. That being said the editing is pretty bad, and the writer could work on some of the finer points of grammar. Another thing is the acronyms. Unless the writer has made the specific items stand out early on, acronyms just become confusing. We all know what an EMP is but not everyone immediately knows what you're referring to when you say things like NVG. With all that I'd still recommend reading it, and these independent writers deserve a chance just for daring to make the effort. If you like this, I'd also recommend 77 Days In September

Only read part of the sample. That was enough for me. Foul language. Errors. And stupidity, such as tossing out a cupful of water after just having said his urine was dark (dehydration setting in); And then a foolish, unnecessary, merciless killing by the so-called hero of the book. Thanks, but no thanks.

Once I got into this book I really, really liked it. made me think a lot about what could happen overnight to the citizens of this country if the government really got serious about " fundamental changes" our "deceptor-in-chief" always talks about. I believe there are a lot of people in this country who think we should "share" the wealth so they don't have to work hard. I share what I can, but it's with my family and extended family. Not with anyone who thinks for whatever reason, that I should share with them, just because. This books sums it all up in a nut shell !!!

"Audio Book Version"  If you like Patriots, Patriot Dawn and One Second After you will love this book!  This was my first audio book and I'm hooked.  It's so easy to just put on the headphones sit back relax and enjoy to the story.  There is a lot of criticism about grammar and editing of the print version in some of the reviews.  I cannot comment on this but I will tell you by the end of the first chapter I was hooked and didn't want to stop listening.  I finished the book in four days and have purchased the second book in the series, so far it's just as good as the first.

The book was a pretty good read for this genre. The one thing that got on my nerves to no end with this book was the constant name dropping of the equipment he had.  As a person that is pretty well prepared, there is no way that 95 percent of people are going to have all top of the line equipment like he did. The maxpedition bags and such are good but will I spend $200 on a bag or should I spend $75 on a bag and have $125 to spend on things to go in it?  It just felt entirely too much like the author was trying to hard with the name dropping but other than that it was a good read.

After reading this first book of the series only a couple of weeks ago, I'm now into book 4. That alone should tell you something. Book 1 is a great portrayal of how a post-apocalyptic event may start. Fast-paced action with a great underlying story, the author pulls you along quickly and you'll suddenly find yourself on the last page and ready for more. Very different from some other post-apocalyptic fiction in that the book does focus more on the survivalist perspective, and really portrays how unprepared most people are, even when they think they have a plan.

Unless you know all the military and survivalist acronyms I do not recommend this book.  Also, this book needs a good proofreader and editor.  There is too much detail put into the wrong parts of the story which is very annoying. Only read the kindle sample so didn't waste any money.

This, the first novel in the series, is well presented.  Character development is pretty good and the plot-line is consistent and strong.  To anyone interested in the "post apocalyptic" genre of stories, I would happily recommend this book because the author does not get bogged down in the detail of preparedness but focuses on the story telling.  Do not get me wrong, there is enough detail in preparedness to keep one interested, but that detail is not overwhelming as it is with some novels in this genre.  "Going Home" is a fun read.

I honestly struggled to get through this e-book. The storyline was okay, the problem was it was so monotonous. I found myself skipping several pages at a time, I pushed myself to finish the book. This book is no "Lights Out" nor "One Second After" the only reason I gave it three stars was for the storyline, if the book had flowed, and not been written so tacky... I really disliked all the profanity, not needed in the abundance that it was used, nor was all the horrible attempts of "Southern dialect."

I did enjoy this book and the story line.  I read it on Kindle with no problems.  If you read it and pay attention you will pick up tidbits of information that will help you if you are in a similar situation.  This is a worthwhile read and events could certainly happen as they are portrayed in this book.  I could see this happening if the event were a hurricane given it's location.  My only suggestion to the author would be to hire an editor that would do a more complete job of cleaning up some of the grammatical errors.

Unlike other similar subject novels, this, and the others in the series, give you not just a vivid picture of life in America after a not-so-farfetched government engineered disaster and takeover, but it instills true camaraderie with the reader and the characters as they struggle to survive. I can also see the author's sense of humor in the characters and their interaction. I read all five of the series back-to-back, and equally enjoyed them all. I'm looking forward to the next installment with anticipation.

The author made this book fun to read, despite the scenario.  Lots of acronyms, some I didn't know, but with a wide who's a nurse, I'm used to it and there's a glossary.  I learned about some very interesting "bug out" items, even though at times the reading was interrupted by a commercial.  Actually, brand name specifics were helpful for my own preparations.  I'm digging into book two and can't wait to continue the saga.  The author seems to be an average kind of common sense guy......I like that.

The plot of this story is excellent.  The grammar is good.  But there is a serious lack of detail in the writing.  All the detail focuses on the gear the protagonist carries instead of what's actually going on.  There are some great action scenes that really could have been written more suspensefully, and there are terrible things he has to go through that are never really discussed.  I would have loved to know what was going on in the characters' heads, but instead I got a gear advertisement.

This book is preachy at best, and often falls into bursts of testosterone as well as federal government (and Obama) bashing.  Gives you an insight into those who feel they are patriots - often lapsing into rambling diatribes about those who take care of themselves, the rest live on the government teat.  If you are a bible thumping, right wing government hating conservative, then you will love this book.
Poorly written.  Couldn't even finish the first chapter.  Sorry.

Some great practical prepping tips included in the storyline.  I liked the characters - however author would build up a  character that you started to get used to, and all of a sudden they're thinking or saying something out of left field - like *thank god I still had some a%% wipes*.  It's almost as if the author wants to make sure we know we're dealing with "manly men".  It felt really jarring and took away from the entire book each time it happened.

I loved the 299 Days series, and this series is on the same level but not as slow. Very good pace and I found that it often left me on the edge of my proverbial seat. I'm on the third book in the series now and I can't put it down. I like that the Author describes some of the products that he writes about abd uses actual manufacturer and model names. It's fun to Google some that interest me and they may find a way into my own prepping supplies.

While he may write with the experience of Stephen King, he also doesn't add 100 pages of fluff and hyperbole like King. The main characters were adequetly developed and by the middle if the book I was literally on the edge of my seat and staying up later than I'd like on worknights. By the time I realized how much I liked the story I couldn't order the remaining books in the series quick enough. Now I must wait a few days for them to arrive.

Hard to put down.  This is a great story about a man, just trying to get home after the SHTF.  The interesting part is that there is also a lot of good information in this story if you pay attention.  I'm sure his choices for gear aren't perfect, no ones is, but there sure will get you headed in the right direction.  I can't wait until book 2 is finished and out.

Pretty good story.  Complex enough to continue sequels until we run out of money.  It'll  wear thin before that.  I know, because I've already read the next few.  For a guy with small children, our hero sure spouts profanities easily--guess that's what tough guys do.  This is the first SHTF book that mentions bears, raccoons chickens, horses, cows, ticks, 'gators, armadillos, dogs, cats, and fish.  Think about that!  Really American.

I picked up this book blind, with no prior knowledge of what to expect. It made a good read, as well as the sequel, "Surviving Home". There were a few instances where I had to back up & read something again, and the antics of the "Sarge" and his crew were a bit over the top at times. But all in all, it was well thought out, with a good story flow, and I enjoyed them both. I look forward to a 3rd book, if there is one in the making.

This series, like most I've encountered in kindle books, has the need for a good editor. I keep my distaste for the distraction of grammatical and poor word choice errors under control by adding a note to it. Sometimes it's as small as "all right" being misspelled as "alright."  This author did well. I often quit reading when I make five notations on a page. The story is excellent, good characters, good story line.

I happen to love this type of book.  This particular story is probably for those of us who actually think (and care) if the end of the world as we know it will happen.  I initially struggled with acronyms and gear names, but ended up making lists to compare to my person stock.  The actual story is gripping and makes you want more.  I feel like Morgan is out there somewhere, making his way home, and I want to be his neighbor!

Feels like the author is a wannabe.  Main character is not rivoting and even seems lazy and lacking in street smarts.  The story is basically about a doomsday prepper who looks good on paper but who I could never really get behind and root for because of his lack of grit/street smarts.  Setting a goal of walking 10 miles a day to get back to your family seems a little weak to me.  Seeing that he is described as 6' 260#, he should have spent more time on the treadmill before the "event".  The book seemed false.

This story is a thinly wrapped fantasy of a shootemup Armageddon/"Revolution" product placement Gall"s catalog. Add some gun talk, military lingo, and some blood and guts. Throw in machismo. Delete any interesting female characters, and you have a perfect middle aged male fantasy without the sex. Guns, paranoia, prepping, stuff, gear, guns, blood and guts, and did I mention guns?

I'll give this Merican classic a solid 2 stars. Not too bad of a read but what do you expect from the survivalist genera when mostly survivalist are writing the e books. But he should change his to A. Mercan

This book, was by far, the worst book I have ever read.  It took me three months to finish it.  Had I not paid money for it I probably would have just thrown it in the trash after the first two chapters.  The story line had some potential.  However, the grammer and dogma drove me nuts!

The first of the series with a lack of good editing, or any editing, almost put me off but the story intrigued me and so I went on to finish the series. Each book progressively got better. I didn't like all the alphabet labels on things, alphabet without a first explanation but, having read enough survivalist type stories, I knew half, guessed at others, and gave up on the rest. The story was pulling me along.

I agree with others that this book could use an editor. There are also several spots in the book where it basically repeats the same sentence close to one another. But I am not going to lower my rating based on that because this was a page turner and I couldn't put it down! I've already started the second book in the series. If you liked the book One Second After I would recommend you read this one also!

Enjoyable read. Who needs zombies when the baser human instincts are much more frightening? Could have used a little editing.....if the Author reads this review, leave contact info at AW Peterson's for Big Sam and I'll be happy to proof your next one, even if I have to drag my tail out of the Green Swamp and head up to Altooner.

Very entertaining story. Plus I always learn a little something from these stories about what my family and I might face if something were to happen in our country. I recommend reading and I'm already half way through #2 in the series. There are a number of skipped words in the text, so the proofreading was probably nonexistent but not so bad that you can't fill in the missing word here and there.

Great book, sure there are some typos etc, but it is a great read, so good in fact I bought the next three in the series. I also bought the audio to go along with the books at a bargain. I have a hard time putting the books down, so I plug my Kindle into my media radio while I am driving & I put the headset on at the Gym, sure makes the time fly. I hope there is a 5 & 6 book coming out soon.

If you like a dose of political opinion in the guise of story telling, buy the thing. If you want a story about an apocalyptic event with good writing, like On the Beach, A Gift Upon the Shore, or Summer of the Apocalypse, pass this one up. It is just a survivalist rant in the guise of fiction in my opinion.

For a first time book, it wasn't bad. It's a bit different, bouncing back and forth between perspectives, but I kind of liked it. There seemed to be no editing of any type. If you aren't to book snobby or OCD about spelling, you'll find this a good read... A few reviewers have made fun of all the things in Morgans bag. I plan to do a weight check to see what that thing really weighed....

What a good one! A very believable story where the individuals have to live more by their whits than a over abundance of stuff.  They end up with some equipment but they do not get it by passing out silver and gold.  This makes it a very believable story.  Great read I can't wait for the next one from the author!

Great Story, Great writer! I've read a lot of fiction and this is right at the top. If they can make movie about "The Postman", this author should already be getting calls from movie producers . It was hard to put the book down each night. I felt like I was walking along with Morgan as he makes the trip home.

Best prepper/societal collapse book series ever written. The story line is gripping, intense and informative all at the same time. It doesn't hurt that the author is about as genuine as they come. Good guy who makes it a point to interact with his readers and seems to have an honest to goodness passion for preparedness. This book and the sequels are highly reccomended.

Could happen, Real, Great Story line!  Captivated me from start to end.  Talk about a possible real life scenario Going Home is, I could literally see myself right there with them.  Definitely going to upgrade my day pack/ bug out bag.  Angery American nailed it with this, the reason I'm on Amazon right now I just purchased the next three books in the series!

AA writing is the best in the Genre drawing you in to each page wanting more.  Not overly tacticool but realistic to what a person or persons may have if they are any type prepared person.  Can't wait for the second book to be finished.  Great read you won't put it down until you're done.

The book held my attention and the survival journey and the interactions and conflicts with people along the way seem very realistic and plausible, but the whole premise about the government orchestrating the whole disaster as a way of disarming and controlling the populace is a stretch.

Good read.  Interesting scenario and story about how fragile "civilization" really is.  Unfortunately, I don't think the premise is that far off from reality.  Will it ever happen?  Probably not, in my life time.  But then again I'm old.

I really enjoyed this book and was interested enough that I finished it and moved on to book two within about 3 days. I was concerned about how I would like it after reading some reviews saying the grammar and quality of editing was poor. I really didn't have an issue with it. I think people are being picky where that is concerned. If you really enjoy this topic, as I do, you will enjoy the book. The writing is fairly simplistic,  like a James Patterson book or something along those lines. In my book that's not a bad thing. It's entertaining and a quick read.  The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is the author jumping between being a little abrupt to giving way too much detail. If you have the book, jump to page 387 for a good example.  The entire page is dedicated to explaining step by step what "Sarge" did to prepare dinner. That level of detail crosses over into the realm of being boring. But....it's not all like that. I'd recommend the series

This book started out as what I expected, a decent story about a prepper who has to use his preps too get home to his family, but by the end it had become about how big brother is trying too take everyone's guns.
Overall it was a good read. A little rough at first but stick with it and enjoy the excitement. I plan on reading the rest of the series.
Really like it!!!

Within the first few pages, you sense that this guy is portrayed as a self extreme survivalist with all the equipment one would only dream of having. More of a fantasy journey he took to arrive back home.
Great story and very believeable characters and plot line.  However the author went a little over board on the details.
Very interesting plot. The language is way over the top. No decent civil society uses the f*** word in every other sentence.

Poorly written, but gives an interesting look into the mind of a prepper. Being prepared won't be so funny when you are stranded and searching for water, warmth, food or even your family. It definitely holds your attention all the way to the end. I'm somewhat curious to see what the next book in the line accomplishes.
Will be ordering the other two books in the trilogy. Easy, interesting read. Nothing spectacular, but good way to pass the hours.

As Pa/SHTF genre there are way more misses than hits.  I felt like this was an above average offering.  The entire series comes off way less preachy than many of its ilk.  The characters a well developed and engaging.  Another thing I liked about this series is that it did not seem to be overly concerned with teaching me prepped/survival lore.  Chances are if you are reading in this genre you already have an interest in survival and don't need to read someone's survival fantasy with their personal gear lists. I also felt that it took a much more respectful tone with regards to politics and religion which are often pushed far too heavily in my opinion.  There is plenty of room in the prepped/survivor community of Americans from the left and the right.  Great series and a good buy.

I enjoyed this book.  At first I got a bit tired of his mention of all the name brand stuff he was carrying and the "magic" backpack that seemed to have everything under the sun in it, but then I really started to enjoy the story.  I actually looked up some of the items he was carrying and found them to be good products to carry.  I find this story to be a very realistic look at what could possibly happen in this situation and it was rather frightening.  Thanks for writing this series and I look forward to book two.

Realistic premise, tends to be repetitive with the gear... always a Springfield .45, never just holstering his pistol.  I understand he has to explain in detail everything to the uneducated so I will cut him some slack.  Like most of these post-EMP novels it could use some editing, but overall it was an enjoyable, quick read. I am currently reading his follow up novel Surviving Home.
This book is well written, informative and very thought provoking.  When things go bad here in the US, the situations in this book could not only become real, but it could be much worse.
I enjoyed the first two books in the Survivalist series - good action / adventure plot with likable characters - happy reading!
Loved this book. Kept me on edge and loved the writing.  Great characters and fast pace. I pictured myself in this book lol because I would do the same things the main character does

I really like this series. This is a guy struggling to get home to his family in the turmoil after an emp. Simple easy read. Almost non stop action. I have read the second book in the series also and I am waiting for the third to come in the mail.

Starts out pretty static, but quickly gets you sitting upright on the edge of your chair. Great read, stimulates your brain and really makes you think about family preparedness.  Even though it's fiction, there are many items of interest and education in the entire series that can make you and your family better prepared for emergencies.
The story needs some proof reading but I really enjoyed it.  Going to read the second in the series next.

Going Home was recommended to me by a friend who is somewhat of a survivalist enthusiast, just like Morgan  the stories main character. I don't normally read stories like this but Going Home was a compulsive experience. One appealing aspect to me was the rapid devolving civility of people, which goes from law biding citizen to nearly savage in just a matter of days. No you want like Morgan sometimes, and some left thinking readers will probably be offended with some of the narratives political assertions. If you can get past this though Going Home is a fun and wild ride.

Kind of amateurish writing at times, and there are a few over-the-top characters that had my eyes rolling.... but, dammit, this guy can spin a story. I took the book on a business trip and found myself not being able to put it down. I'm looking forward to reading the sequel.

It's hard to find well written books in this genre. Most are either too preachy, poorly written, or just plain bad. I found this series to actually be very entertaining. A little more time should have been spent proof reading the book but if you look past those rare mistakes the you will enjoy this book.
Needs to expand more on prepping needs and how Morgan went about getting supplies. Will read the other books in the series for sure.
A well written story and very realistic in both the scenarios challenging each character and their approach to survive post-EMP social chaos.

Very revealing and somewhat true for the type of book it was written for.  Everyone should read these series of books.  Most people think it can't happen.  They need to rethink that and start prepping.
Great read! Some things were over my head as far as lingo and procedure but still a fast, enjoyable read.
I hate giving reviews but this book was a pretty good read. Believable story and fairly good character development. Worth buying

I've read many of the other comments about this book.  Some complain about the grammar and writing skill of the author.  Ok, so it ain't purfect.  I enjoyed it just for the topic, giving me pleny of ideas what it would be like to actually live out this scenario.  I've lived in the South for many year before finally coming home to Gods country (Colorado).  I would argue that it's written just as the Southerners talk - since it's written about GA-FL area.  I could just see my redneck buddies using these exact words/phrases.  So take it for what it is, an enjoyable read.  I've read the first two books, and am getting the third.
Really, really good book and entertaining.  Like all books of this genre, there are some things that are a little unbelievable, but the story is fantastic
All three books were a good fun read. Sometimes useless details got in the way go the story but overall a fun read.
the book held my attention. it also mentioned things I had not thought of. also mentions good sources of information in the glossary.

Enjoyed the book and am continuing to read the series.  Thought the story was compelling and well written.  The lay out and organization of the story keeps you interested throughout the book, without giving you too much fluff.
I could have done without all the brand name gear descriptions, but a good story. It appears that most of the editing the book lacked when first reviewed has been done. Much better now.

This book was good, held my attention and had some good information. The end came suddenly though and I realize it sets up for the next book, but the end is very sudden just sort of drops. I did get, and finished the next one and plan on the 3rd as well so it didn't deter me form continuing with the story.
I'll be looking for more from this writer. I gave it 3 stars because of the editing towards the last third of the story. It could be cleaner, but still a solid story.

Well written and reasonably faced paced story that is both believable but fantastic enough to be engaging. A. American writes in a style similar to James Rawles without the excruciating detail that JWR is known for and not as heavy handed on the morality
Good read. Not too ramboish and lots of plausible scenarios. I was very entertained and thats all I want in a good book. Ordering Surviving Home the sequel now.
This book will make you think, especially with the events currently taking place today. The story gets a little drawn out....but overall, it's a good read.
I like this series. I'm a fan of this genre.  I have read me many books of its type and this is a good story. good enough that I bought the next one. give it a try.

I like this genre but have found most books are both amateurishly written, but far worse, surprisingly lacking in research and information about the subject. Our hero here walked 200 miles home without a single mention of the weather, critical as rain would be in fresh water-challenged Florida when the pumps went down. Most other books overlook this little rain detail, but also much, more more--the genesis of my "actually finished it" comment asa two others have been put aside. This one was enjoyable and also one of the more thoughtful treatments I've come on so far, although none of them have been outstanding in that respect.
The book was pretty good, but I felt like this guy was getting paid to advertise survival gear. Otherwise okay.

I generally liked this story, moved a good pace and some interesting characters. It was a bit hard to swallow the reason for the whole situation IMO but that's OK...and I did get a little sick of how every single member of a certain organization was portrayed as inhumanly evil.

A four star rating, maybe really a three and a half star for sure. Mr. American shows in this first book a definite learning curve in action. If you can get past some of the rough bumps in the read, it actually turns into a good book. My confidence in his abilities to write a great book is proven by my purchase and comment of his next book; Surviving Home. Start with this one as it does lead respectfully into the next book.
I have read several series involving apocalypse scenarios and I think this might be the best written. I recommend this book to the selective reader who wants their fiction to be realistic.
Another great book.  I have become attached to the characters in this story and can wait for the next book.
Lots of detail. Almost too much. It could get kind of boring at times. This could happen, though I certainly hope not.
A book written from a few perspectives about surviving after a world changing event. I found it very entertaining and actually makes you think about what you would do in the same situation.
Good premise that integrates a plausible situation with a preppers to die for gear list.  Would have liked to read more about different aspects of the society breakdown but it was entertaining.
well written with a very possible scenario and good characters. the plot moves along pretty well bud it leaves you looking for more at the end for the next chapter.
Good read!  It was hard to put down.  I got into the characters and will buy next book in series.

Great book. I couldn't put it down once I started reading. I'm a retired Marine, so the rough language was pretty typical of what you hear when working with warriors. I would have given it 5 stars except that there are quite a few misspelled words but I got over that because it has a great storyline and flowed really. well. Can't wait for the next one to come out.

I wasn't sure what this book was about. Once I started it, I was quickly prepared to dislike it. The politics are not mine, and I am not a prepper. The writing style isn't very good - stock characters, gratuitous swearing, frequent and unnecessary descriptions of bodily functions. Morgan, the main character is egotistical. Thad reminded me of Travis McGee, a big man with an even bigger heart. Jess is the ingenue. Sarge, well Sarge is mysterious. I was tempted to put it down for other books that were calling my name. But, for some reason, I kept going, and I found myself enjoying the story. As the main characters go their separate ways, the plot gets more complex. Exactly what event has caused the grid to go down isn't clear, nor is it clear if the issue expands beyond the U.S.A. While the author skims the surface of deeper questions, I had to stop and think about what would cause me to kill another human being. How could I justify something like that. Morgan gets through this issue very quickly. Thad and Jess struggle. I will probably look at the sequel. I'm hoping that now that a mainstream publisher has picked up the book, better editing will improve the writer's style. And, I want to know more about Thad, Jess, and Sarge. I must admit, Morgan doesn't interest me very much, at least not yet.

No car, no internet, no cell phones, and not alot of police law and order. Every man for himself and survival of the fittest and most prepared. How would you get home to your family if every modern means of transport and communication suddenly died? What things should you carry in your vehicle 'just in case'? The main character, Morgan, has all the answers.

if post disaster is your thing, this book is for you.  although the book needs an editor for some spelling errors, it is a look at the need to be ready to take care of yourself, that the government may not have the best of intentions.

An "event" leaves Morgan a keen survivalist stranded miles from home. The story describes the adventure, danger and the gear he uses during his journey home. I have rated the book with 3 stars normally it would be a 4 star book but the overuse of acronyms and branding has killed off that star. Morgan joins forces with some others also seeking to go home, building friendships and together confronting all the hurdles placed along their route. Very little background is given as to how the event happened and the causes, I suspect this maybe reserved for the second book "Surviving Home". Overall it is a good story however you are distracted by the specialist indulgence.
